newsitem.title: USA: US 30-, 15-yr mortgage rates inch up in wk--FHLMC.
newsitem.headline: US 30-, 15-yr mortgage rates inch up in wk--FHLMC.

text.p: The average commitment rates on U.S. 30- and 15-year fixed-rate mortgages inched upward in the week ending January 17, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp said on Thursday.
The 30-year interest rate rose to an average 7.87 percent in the week from 7.85 percent the previous week, while the 15-year inched up to 7.38 percent from 7.35 percent.
Adjustable-rate mortgages also rose slightly in the week to an average 5.57 percent from 5.54 percent.
A year ago, the 30-year rate averaged 7.02 percent, the 15-year 6.53 percent, and the ARM 5.48 percent.

"Tuesday's release of the consumer price index showed a modest increase, which was in line with what the market was expecting," Frank Nothaft, Freddie Mac deputy chief economist, said. "This helped to comfort the market that price-inflation is under control."

The Labor Department on Tuesday said U.S. consumer prices rose 0.3 percent in December. "Since this caused interest rates to move very little, mortgage rates remained almost exactly the same," Nothaft said.
Last Friday the Labor Department also reported a 262,000 increase in U.S. December nonfarm payrolls and a jobless rate of 5.3 percent.

Freddie Mac said lenders charged an average 1.8 percent in fees and points on 30-year loans, unchanged from last week. They charged 1.7 percent on the 15-year, down from 1.8 percent last week, and 1.4 percent on the ARM, unchanged from last week.
